dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObjects.title: Range Description
dataObjects.rights: © International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources
dataObjects.rightsHolder: International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources
dataObjects.bibliographicCitation: Crandall, K.A. 2010. Procambarus fallax. In: IUCN 2014 . IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. Version 2014.1 . <www.iucnredlist.org>
dataObjects.description: This species is found in the tributaries of the Satilla River, Georgia, and southward through peninsular Florida (Hobbs 1942). This species has a distribution of approximately 87000 km2.

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObjects.title: National Distribution
dataObjects.description:
United States

Origin: Native

Regularity: Regularly occurring

Currently: Present

Confidence: Confident

Type of Residency: Year-round

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObjects.description: Global Range: (20,000-200,000 square km (about 8000-80,000 square miles)) It is found in the tributaries of the Satilla River, Georgia, and southward through peninsular Florida (Hobbs, 1942) extending onto some of the keys.

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat
dataObjects.description:
Habitat Type: Freshwater

Comments: It is a very variable species in its habitat and is considered to be a habitat generalist, inhabiting both lentic and lotic situations It is found in lentic such as ditches, and lotic situations and burrows (Hobbs 1942). Hobbs (1942) indicates that this species has a very variable habitat range, and will occur in any freshwater habitat providing there is sufficient vegetation to provide protection from predators.

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Migration
dataObjects.description:
Non-Migrant: No. All populations of this species make significant seasonal migrations.

Locally Migrant: No. No populations of this species make local extended movements (generally less than 200 km) at particular times of the year (e.g., to breeding or wintering grounds, to hibernation sites).

Locally Migrant: No. No populations of this species make annual migrations of over 200 km.

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#PopulationBiology
dataObjects.title: Global Abundance
dataObjects.description:
10,000 to >1,000,000 individuals

Comments: Hobbs (1942) recorded 1844 specimens and stated that it is one of the most common species in the north-central part of the Florida peninsular.

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#ConservationStatus
dataObjects.title: NatureServe Conservation Status
dataObjects.description:
Rounded Global Status Rank: G5 - Secure

Reasons: This species has a huge distribution throughout the Florida peninsular and into Georgia. It is a very variable species in its habitat and is considered to be a habitat generalist, inhabiting both lentic and lotic situations. It is considered to be one of the most common crayfish species in the Florida peninsular.

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Trends
dataObjects.description: Global Short Term Trend: Relatively stable (=10% change)
